prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want my hair fixed, for free, by the hairdresser?
[What I showed her](http://imgur.com/KmuiLRL)


[What I got](http://imgur.com/gEiWAi4)


I asked my stylist to do a light brown rose gold, and emphasized that I wanted it a light brown, warm color.

I showed her the picture more than a week in advance of the appointment so she had time to get any colors she didn’t have. 

I told her multiple times I wanted a light brown.  I know you can’t perfectly match the picture, but I think I made it obvious I wanted more brown than red in my hair.  I would have been fine without the rose tint.  My hair was bleach blonde to begin with.

She’s going to try to fix it but I don’t think I should have to pay, this is clearly not what I asked for.  Am I the asshole?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong in the situation described. The author went to a hairdresser and showed them a picture of a light brown rose gold color, emphasizing they wanted a light brown, warm color. They mentioned it was a week before the appointment, so the stylist had time to prepare. The result was something with more red and rose tint, which the author didn't want. Now they're saying they don't want to pay for the fix.

First, I need to consider the details. The author clearly communicated their request multiple times and provided a reference image. The stylist didn't deliver what was agreed upon. The author's hair was already bleached blonde, so maybe the stylist didn't account for the base color properly. The main issue is whether the author is at fault for not getting the desired result.

Hairdressers are professionals, and clients expect them to match the requested color. If the stylist didn't follow instructions despite multiple reminders, that's probably on them. The author isn't asking for a perfect match but a color close to what was discussed. Since the result is significantly different, it's reasonable for the author to expect a free fix. The question is whether the author is wrong to refuse paying for the mistake. 

In many cases, if a service doesn't meet the agreed standard, the client isn't obligated to pay for corrections. The author's stance here is that the error was the stylist's, so they shouldn't pay. That seems fair. So the answer would be B (No, the author isn't in the wrong). The key points are clear communication from the client and the professional being responsible for the error.
